Title.evidence: Cost-Effectiveness of Dual Hypothermic Oxygenated Machine Perfusion in DCD Liver Transplantation: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: patients were randomised to receive a DCD liver preserved with either DHOPE or SCS

Participants.evidence: The trial took place in three Dutch liver transplant centers.

Intervention.evidence: patients were randomised to receive a DCD liver preserved with either DHOPE or SCS

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the cost-effectiveness of dual hypothermic oxygenated machine perfusion (DHOPE) versus static cold storage (SCS) in donation after circulatory death (DCD) liver transplantation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the cost-effectiveness of DHOPE, evaluated by total medical costs up to one year posttransplant.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Patients and organ procurement teams were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 119 patients were randomised: 60 to DHOPE and 59 to SCS.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean total cost per patient was €110,794 for DHOPE and €126,221 for SCS, with significant reductions in intensive care costs (28.4%) and nonsurgical interventions (24.3%).

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by national healthcare bodies
